description: Compound of clod +â€Ž hopper (agentive form of the verb hop). Perhaps affected by analogy with grasshopper. Attested in the sense of "peasant" since the seventeenth century; the extended sense of "boot" or "shoe" dates from the nineteenth century.

entries.meaning: A strong shoe for heavy-duty use, a boot.
examples: ...who had got on his "hill shoes," as he calls a pair of clodhoppers as thick as a ploughman's, and stuck round with nails.
We had to walk slow because of his wooden clod-hoppers, and that was the way I wanted it now

entries.meaning: (military slang) United States Navy ankle length work shoes, distinct from dress shoes or combat boots.
examples: Smiling Jim Mead of New York tries on his GI clodhopper boots. He decided to return them "because we couldn't make any altitude with those aboard."

'Nephew Jack,' he cried, looking at me when I was thinking what to say, and finding only emptiness, 'you are a heavy lout, sir; a bumpkin, a clodhopper; and I shall leave you nothing, unless it be my boots to grease.'
All guess-work exploits shrivel up a good yard, or sometimes two, when brought to the measure, and the champion of the county dwindles into a clumsy clod-hopper.

entries.meaning: Wheatear; any of various passerine birds.
